caseTitle: ACADEMY OF AFRICAN MUSIC & ARTS LTD. & BORTIANOR STOOL VERSUS IN THE SUPERIOR COURT
summary: This appeal arose from a land dispute in which the respondent claimed ownership of land in the Greater Accra Region based on a 1973 purchase from the Abredze family of Gomoa Nyanyanor and registration as No. 1498/1977. The appellants, including Musstafa Tettey Addy and the Bortianor Stool, claimed ownership through traditional title from Kokrobite and Bortianor stools. The Court of Appeal overturned the High Court’s judgment in favor of the respondent, holding that the respondent’s case rested on inquiry 2/79, which was based on earlier inquiries (14/75 and 10/76) that had been set aside by the Stool Lands Boundary Appeals Tribunal. Thus, the foundation of the respondent’s claim had collapsed. Additionally, the respondent failed to call his grantors to prove how they acquired allodial title, placing the burden of proof on him which he did not meet. The court emphasized that registration alone does not confer title and that traditional ownership requires evidentiary support. The appellants’ traditional evidence, including the use of Lanma Hill as a boundary marker, was unchallenged. Consequently, the respondent’s claims for declaration of title, trespass damages, recovery of possession, and injunction failed. The appeal was allowed, and the judgment in favor of the respondent was set aside.
verdict: Appeal allowed; judgment in favor of the respondent set aside.
rationaleHighlights: The trial court erred in relying on inquiry 2/79, which was based on inquiries 14/75 and 10/76 that had been set aside.
The respondent failed to call his grantors as witnesses to prove how they acquired allodial title, rendering exhibit A insufficient.
Registration of a land document does not confer state-guaranteed title or prove ownership per se.
The disputed land lies deep within the Greater Accra Region, surrounded by Ga lands, raising a presumption against Fanti ownership without proof.
The appellants' traditional evidence, including the significance of Lanma Hill, was unchallenged and supported their claim.
